briefing.opening: Good morning/afternoon, everyone. I will now begin the climate briefing for December 24, 2025.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Direct Impacts of Climate Change and Economic Ripple Effects
sections.content: News collected today clearly demonstrates that climate change is no longer a distant future problem, but one that directly impacts our lives and economy right now. In the United States, rising beef prices due to climate change are affecting Christmas dinners and placing a significant burden on households [3, 9, 43], aligning with research indicating a 12% decrease in U.S. income [28]. In Asia, typhoon precipitation in Japan has tripled, significantly increasing disaster risk [4, 44, 120], and domestically, the agricultural sector is taking a direct hit with reduced cabbage and apple production [5]. Furthermore, over half of coastal settlements worldwide are relocating inland, and the domestic aquaculture industry faces a crisis of collapse [51, 53, 125], demonstrating that climate change is not merely a future threat but a present reality. These economic and social ripple effects are also severely impacting the macroeconomy, with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) pointing to climate change-induced monetary policy risks [144].

sections.title: âš ï¸ Changing Christmas Landscapes and Ecosystem Crisis
sections.content: As Christmas approaches, warnings continue that climate change is altering even our familiar landscapes. Concerns have been raised that the rapid decline in reindeer populations in the Arctic region could lead to the disappearance of Christmas symbols like snow and trees [8, 21, 130, 131]. This phenomenon clearly illustrates the widespread impact of climate change on ecosystems. Research showing that Greenlandic polar bears exhibit genetic changes to survive climate change [132] suggests that species are making desperate efforts to adapt to new environments.

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Corporate and Local Government Efforts and Achievements in Carbon Neutrality
sections.content: Despite challenging climate conditions, the efforts of corporations and local governments to address climate change are leading to positive outcomes. Hankook Tire has been recognized for its carbon emission reduction efforts, achieving the highest 'A' rating for two consecutive years in the CDP (Carbon Disclosure Project) climate change response category [1, 7, 10, 42]. The Hyundai Motor Chung Mong-koo Foundation received a Presidential Commendation for its contributions to carbon-neutral green growth [57, 58, 60], and Samcheok City and the Korea Energy Agency also received Prime Minister's Commendations for their carbon neutrality efforts, acknowledging their contributions to local communities and the nation [63, 75, 78]. Leading ESG management by large corporations is expanding, with LG Group setting a 2050 carbon neutrality target and Shinhan Bank supporting the growth of green unicorns [80, 90]. Internationally, global companies' efforts to address climate change continue, as Fast Retailing has been selected for the CDP 'A List' for four consecutive years [124].

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Domestic Climate Crisis Adaptation Strategies and Renewable Energy Policy Trends
sections.content: The South Korean government and local authorities are pursuing various strategies for climate crisis adaptation and achieving carbon neutrality. The government plans to introduce AI-based flood and drought forecasting systems and advance national climate crisis adaptation strategies through the enactment of a 'Special Act on Climate Adaptation' [41, 22, 47]. Furthermore, policy support is being strengthened for the expansion of renewable energy, with the Ministry of Climate holding regional policy briefings and the promotion of legislation to ease regulations on the separation distance for renewable energy facilities [111, 112, 113, 115]. Concrete implementation measures are also being sought at the community level, such as Suncheon City's promotion of an RE-100 industrial complex [20, 46, 49], Gwangju City's carbon neutrality point system [54, 103, 109], and Hwaseong Special City's operation of a 2050 Carbon Neutrality and Green Growth Committee [67]. As a result of these efforts, the Presidential Commission on Carbon Neutrality and Green Growth (PCCNGG) shared its achievement of exceeding the 2024 greenhouse gas reduction target by 4.0% [101].

sections.title: ğŸŒ International Community's Climate Change Communication and Research Trends
sections.content: In the international community, increased awareness of climate change and new research trends are being reported. In New York City, greenhouse gas emissions have decreased to pandemic levels, suggesting a positive impact of local climate regulations [123], and an author's perspective was presented that China is also seeking a 'constructive role' in climate change [121]. A Kenyan filmmaker demonstrated how to communicate about climate change in Africa to the world [129], emphasizing the importance of raising awareness through cultural approaches. Meanwhile, research in Greenland indicates that the complex interplay of climate change and geological processes is having unique effects [137], alongside findings that polar bears exhibit genetic changes to survive climate change [132], highlighting the complex adaptation patterns of ecosystems.

briefing.closing: This concludes today's climate briefing. Sustained attention and effort towards climate change are critically needed at this time.
